content.description:
Cool route with some really steep ice! First crux usually involves a little mixed climbing to get past the rock overhang to the main ice flow, the second crux is finishing through the vertical/overhanging ice to the belay ledge. 
 P1 WI5+, M5; Climb easy ice to the overhang about 30' up where some rock moves are usually necessary. Pull through the overhang to the ice above. Continue up good ice and climb through very steep ice to a ledge and build a belay. 
 P2 WI4: Move left from the ledge and finish P2 of Child's Play.

The start is about 10m right of Child's Play. Most parties rappel after P1.
Mostly screws but small cams/stoppers may be helpful, depending on how far the ice comes past the overhang. Build a v-thread anchor at the top of P1, use a tree anchor at the top of the route.

double stepped ice climb easily visible from Feaver road

tree anchors

When you think a route might go in one direction, but it doesn't, and it's totally awesome! Adam gets the credit for us going up and sniffing this one out. Where the ice ended, he envisioned traversing left under some blocky roofs to find a way up. But there was this beautiful crack directly above, and it took us all the way to the top! 
  
 P1: M6 65m  Climb thin and intermittent ice at the left margin of where Mise en Sense forms.   
 P2: M8 35m  Climb up left of the tree to gain the crack, then climb through the overhang into a slot. A couple moves up the slot, step out of it to the left and up (crux) to a blocky ledge. Work back to the crack and follow it to the top. The crack is parallel-sided and you'll enjoy having extra C4 2's and 3's.

Les Incompetent is 5m left of Mise en Sense, and about 20m to the right of Chucky's Revenge.  Top rappel from a tree, lower rappel from a v-thread.
Screws, draws, set of stoppers and C3's, double set C4's + a 3rd #2 and #3.

Another McRae 4-star route! A super fun steep, sustained, and engaging line.

P1: M6+, 45m. Begin on seeps directly below the main ice smear up high. Climb a left-facing corner to a bolt, then left and up the corner past several more bolts to a no-hands stance below a short headwall, then up to a bolted station on the left.  This pitch is a bit chossy for the first 10-15m.

P2: M8, WI6, 60m.  From the belay climb on small but positive edges to the ice, clipping a few bolts along the way. Climb ice (30m) to its end, then up the mixed corner and through a slightly overhanging offwidth(crux). Finish off the corner and some umbrellas at the top, and belay/rappel from a tree.

This isn't a sport route! Distance between bolts is sporty. Also, before climbing, check to be sure there is a good smear of ice on the second pitch. Refer to the beta photo for reference.



Approach as for Pukasahib and Nanibijou, and continue about 100m past Nanibijou.

10 Draws for bolts, screws (10-17cm), a few small cams. Bolted belay/rap station at the top of P1. P2 is ALL of 60m, watch your ends on rappel.

Like the other routes on McRae, Nanibijou hasn't been forming every year, so get it when you can!  
 P1, WI4:  Climb thin, variable ice for  about 40'  to a short vertical step through a rock band, and hopefully thicker ice. Continue up steep ice to a bolted station on the right. DO NOT continue higher and belay from the alcove, as you will get pounded by ice coming off P2. 
 P2, WI5: Move up and right from the belay and climb a variety of ice features, sometimes awkward, in an occasionally tight chimney. Work through steep mushrooms and umbrellas at the top to find the tree anchor. VARIATION to P2 goes left from the belay and climbs the left side of the chimney. This rarely done variation usually involves insecure mixed climbing.

About 100 meters left of Child's Play.
Screws for pro, bolted belay/rappel anchor at the top of pitch 1, tree anchor at the top of the route.

Great and long route. Initial WI4 ice leads to chandeliered ice ledges and curtains with the route's technical crux. The crux is followed by 80ft of pumpy WI5 climbing to the ledge with belay (v-threads, ice screws). From here, second pitch of WI4 leads to the top.

Northwest face of Mt. McRae.
Ice screws, rock gear is useful in thin conditions (c3's, small to medium nuts). Cords for v-threads at the belay. Double 60m ropes needed for the comfortable lead of the first pitch.

pathTokens: LAKE SUPERIOR W: Marathon to Thunder Bay, includes Kama and Orient Bay
Thunder Bay Region Ice and Mixed

content.description: Mount McRae sits in the northern end of the mountain system of mafic sills, known as Nor'Wester Mountains. Extending south of Thunder Bay, Nor'Wester Mountains define the landscape immediately after crossing to Canada and driving along Provincial Route 61. Mount McRae's northern neighbor, Mount McKay, the tallest of these mountains, looms over Thunder Bay and is the city's defining landmark.
